constraint_text: Valentine has confided her destiny to Morrel
source_excerpt: he to whom you have confided your destiny

constraint_text: Death would have separated Valentine from Morrel
source_excerpt: he from whom death would have separated you

constraint_text: Monte Cristo has vanquished death
source_excerpt: Happily, I vanquished death.

constraint_text: Albert is an elegant, well‑looking young man
source_excerpt: Albert, besides being an elegant, well‑looking young man, was also possessed of considerable talent and ability;

constraint_text: Albert possesses considerable talent and ability
source_excerpt: Albert, besides being an elegant, well‑looking young man, was also possessed of considerable talent and ability;

constraint_text: Albert is a viscount, a recently created one
source_excerpt: moreover, he was a viscount—a recently created one, certainly,

constraint_text: Albert commands an income of 50,000 livres, making him a person of considerable importance in Paris
source_excerpt: Albert de Morcerf commanded an income of 50,000 livres, a more than sufficient sum to render him a personage of considerable importance in Paris.

constraint_text: Dantès was arrested on 28 February 1815 at half‑past two in the afternoon.
source_excerpt: The 28th of February, 1815, at half-past two in the afternoon.

constraint_text: Dantès was mad when he tried to kill the turnkey.
source_excerpt: but I was mad.

constraint_text: Captivity has subdued Dantès, changing his demeanor.
source_excerpt: captivity has subdued me—I have been here so long.

constraint_text: The petition (application) is dated 10th April 1815.
source_excerpt: perused, too, the application dated 10th April, 1815, in which Morrel, by the deputy procureur’s advice, exaggerated with the best intentions (for Napoleon was then on the throne) the services Dantès had rendered to the imperial cause—services which Villefort’s certificates rendered indisputable.

constraint_text: He is described as an inveterate Bonapartist, a trait that persists over his lifespan.
source_excerpt: An inveterate Bonapartist; took an active part in the return from the Island of Elba.

constraint_text: He is to be kept in strict solitary confinement and to be closely watched and guarded.
source_excerpt: To be kept in strict solitary confinement, and to be closely watched and guarded.

constraint_text: Andrea must not jest.
source_excerpt: "Do not let us jest," gravely replied Bertuccio

constraint_text: Andrea must not utter that name again.
source_excerpt: "dare not to utter that name again as you have pronounced it."

constraint_text: Andrea is a wretch.
source_excerpt: "the father of such a wretch as you."

constraint_text: The Count of Monte Cristo is too highly favored by Heaven.
source_excerpt: "the person who bears it is too highly favored by Heaven"

constraint_text: Mercédès was much changed within the last few days.
source_excerpt: Mercédès was much changed within the last few days

constraint_text: Mercédès's eye no longer sparkled.
source_excerpt: her eye no longer sparkled

constraint_text: Mercédès's lips no longer smiled.
source_excerpt: her lips no longer smiled

constraint_text: There is now a hesitation in Mercédès's utterance of words that formerly sprang fluently from her ready wit.
source_excerpt: there was now a hesitation in uttering the words which formerly sprang so fluently from her ready wit

constraint_text: Mercédès's broken spirit was not caused by poverty, and her poverty was not burdensome because of a lack of courage.
source_excerpt: It was not poverty which had broken her spirit; it was not a want of courage which rendered her poverty burdensome.

constraint_text: Because he lived in Marseilles, the country house was useless to him
source_excerpt: M. de Saint-Méran lived at Marseilles, so that this country house was useless to him

constraint_text: The country house was let to her (the Baroness)
source_excerpt: it was reported to be let to a young widow, known only by the name of ‘the Baroness’

constraint_text: She was between eighteen and nineteen years old
source_excerpt: she was from eighteen to nineteen

constraint_text: Glenarvan's eye could clearly distinguish the least depressions of the earth.
source_excerpt: the mist had dissolved under the rays of the sun, and his eye could clearly distinguish the least depressions of the earth.

constraint_text: No movement of the Maoris could escape Glenarvan's sight.
source_excerpt: No movement of the Maoris could escape his sight.

constraint_text: At least a year had elapsed since his arrival on the island, his presentation to the smuggler chief, the subterranean palace, the supper, and the spoonful of hashish.
source_excerpt: It seemed, however, even in the very face of open day, that at least a year had elapsed since all these things had passed

constraint_text: Thalcave has never, during his time as a guide, walked on soil this saturated.
source_excerpt: Never within his recollection, since he had performed the office of guide, had his feet trodden a soil so saturated.

constraint_text: When he perceives nothing that could enlighten him, he resumes his undeviating course.
source_excerpt: perceiving nothing that could enlighten him, he resumed his undeviating course

constraint_text: Jacopo is a Corsican
source_excerpt: We had forgotten to say that Jacopo was a Corsican.

constraint_text: Jacopo was instructed by Edmond
source_excerpt: Edmond, with a chart in his hand, became the instructor of Jacopo

constraint_text: After two months and a half of the trips, Edmond had become as skilful a coaster as he had been a hardy seaman
source_excerpt: Two months and a half elapsed in these trips, and Edmond had become as skilful a coaster as he had been a hardy seaman

constraint_text: Edmond formed an acquaintance with all the smugglers on the coast
source_excerpt: he had formed an acquaintance with all the smugglers on the coast

constraint_text: Edmond learned all the Masonic signs used by the half pirates
source_excerpt: and learned all the Masonic signs by which these half pirates recognize each other

constraint_text: Julie (and her husband) have known unhappiness in the past.
source_excerpt: "We are very happy, monsieur," replied Julie; "but we have also known unhappiness, and few have ever undergone more bitter sufferings than ourselves."

constraint_text: The count has experienced bitter sorrows over his life.
source_excerpt: "... we have experienced bitter sorrows."

constraint_text: He moves in the first Parisian circles because of his personal merit rather than his social position.
source_excerpt: for M. de Villefort moved in the first Parisian circles, less owing to his social position than to his personal merit.

constraint_text: He does not exact a mournful face or force tears from others.
source_excerpt: who did not exact a mournful face or force tears, as would have been the case with a father, a brother, or a lover.

constraint_text: Glenarvan is accustomed to Ayrton's manners, indicating a long‑standing familiarity with Ayrton's behavior.
source_excerpt: Glenarvan, who was accustomed to Ayrton's manners, betrayed no surprise

constraint_text: The quality of jewellers' imitations has made robbing a jeweller's shop no longer worthwhile.
source_excerpt: but those thieves of jewellers imitate so well that it is no longer worthwhile to rob a jeweller’s shop—it is another branch of industry paralyzed

constraint_text: He is a talker
source_excerpt: Even without his speaking you felt that he was a talker

constraint_text: He is abstracted, not noticing what he sees or hears
source_excerpt: he was abstracted, after the manner of those who do not see what they are looking at or hear what they are listening to

constraint_text: He possesses a strong curiosity
source_excerpt: The curiosity of this unknown being was a singular contrast to the calmness of the major

constraint_text: He is wearing a traveling cap, stout yellow buskins, leather gaiters, maroon velvet pantaloons, and a matching jacket with innumerable pockets
source_excerpt: He wore a traveling cap, stout yellow buskins and leather gaiters, pantaloons of maroon velvet, and a jacket of the same material, whose innumerable pockets seemed stuffed with note-books, memoranda, scraps, portfolios, and a thousand articles as inconvenient as they were useless

constraint_text: He carries a four‑foot telescope in a sling
source_excerpt: not to speak of a telescope which he carried in a sling

constraint_text: Morcerf did not make the promise to never mention the circumstance.
source_excerpt: "It was not I who made that promise," cried Morcerf; "it must have been someone else whom you have rescued in the same manner, and whom you have forgotten.

constraint_text: The narrator's survival (not sleeping in the Catacombs of St. Sebastian) is due to Monte Cristo's generous intercession.
source_excerpt: "Tell them yourself that I was taken by bandits, and that without your generous intercession I should now have been sleeping in the Catacombs of St. Sebastian, instead of receiving them in my humble abode in the Rue du Helder."

constraint_text: the marriage has been discussed for eight years
source_excerpt: have you not had enough time for reflection during the eight years which have elapsed since this marriage was first discussed between us?

constraint_text: Danglars previously said that Morcerf appeared forgetful and irresolute concerning the marriage
source_excerpt: in one of your late conversations with him, you said that I appeared to be forgetful and irresolute concerning this marriage, did you not?

constraint_text: Danglars considers Monte Cristo a particular friend and sees him very often
source_excerpt: I see him very often, ... he is a particular friend of mine.

constraint_text: Dantès was to be married in an hour and intended to start for Paris the next day before being arrested.
source_excerpt: Morrel, all the forms were got over; in a word I was, as I told you, at my marriage feast; and I should have been married in an hour, and tomorrow I intended to start for Paris, had I not been arrested on this charge which you as well as I now see to be unjust.

constraint_text: Dantès' imprudence was in obedience to the orders of his captain.
source_excerpt: If you have been culpable, it was imprudence, and this imprudence was in obedience to the orders of your captain.

constraint_text: The letter Dantès brought was taken from him with other letters.
source_excerpt: You have it already, for it was taken from me with some others which I see in that packet.

constraint_text: Danglars had sold his shares before the market crash.
source_excerpt: Danglars, who had sold his shares

constraint_text: Don Carlos has not left Bourges (he remains in Bourges).
source_excerpt: The king (Don Carlos) has not left Bourges

constraint_text: The family line of Count Spada is extinct.
source_excerpt: No, no, be easy on that score; the family is extinct.

constraint_text: Faria was made the heir by the last Count of Spada.
source_excerpt: The last Count of Spada, moreover, made me his heir, bequeathing to me this symbolic breviary, he bequeathed to me all it contained;

constraint_text: Faria believes they can enjoy the fortune without remorse.
source_excerpt: No, no, make your mind satisfied on that point. If we lay hands on this fortune, we may enjoy it without remorse.

constraint_text: The Cavalcanti family has historically commanded armies and governed provinces.
source_excerpt: for the Cavalcanti have commanded armies and governed provinces

constraint_text: The Cavalcanti family traditionally buries their wealth and passes the locations to their eldest sons.
source_excerpt: they have buried their millions in corners, the secret of which they have transmitted only to their eldest sons, who have done the same from generation to generation

constraint_text: The physical appearance of Cavalcanti family members reflects their wealth.
source_excerpt: and the proof of this is seen in their yellow and dry appearance, like the florins of the republic, which, from being constantly gazed upon, have become reflected in them

constraint_text: His father's position is good
source_excerpt: “...and his father’s position is good.”

constraint_text: He is well educated
source_excerpt: “He is well educated.”

constraint_text: He is very rich
source_excerpt: “And he is very rich.”

constraint_text: He was made a member of the learned assembly within the last week.
source_excerpt: Within the last week he has been made one of the learned assembly.

constraint_text: His talent consists of thrusting pins through the heads of rabbits, making fowls eat madder, and punching the spinal marrow out of dogs with whalebone.
source_excerpt: His talent? I believe he thrusts pins through the heads of rabbits, he makes fowls eat madder, and punches the spinal marrow out of dogs with whalebone.

constraint_text: His style of writing is very good.
source_excerpt: No; that his style of writing is very good.

constraint_text: The coat he wears is not his own idea; it was devised by the Republic, which deputed David12 to create a uniform for the Academicians.
source_excerpt: Oh, that coat is not his own idea; it is the Republic’s, which deputed David12 to devise a uniform for the Academicians.

constraint_text: He is in his fifth year of captivity
source_excerpt: He is now in his fifth year of captivity

constraint_text: He has offered progressively larger sums of money each year for his release, increasing from one million francs in the first year to five million francs in the fifth year
source_excerpt: The first year he offered government a million of francs for his release; the second, two; the third, three; and so on progressively. He is now in his fifth year of captivity; he will ... offer you five millions.

constraint_text: the captain believes that people ought always to help one another
source_excerpt: “Alas,” returned the captain with an accent of the most profound pity, “we ought always to help one another.

constraint_text: ordered a second carriage for himself that left at four o’clock to fetch him from the Rospoli Palace
source_excerpt: the Count of Monte Cristo had ordered a second carriage for himself, and that it had gone at four o’clock to fetch him from the Rospoli Palace

constraint_text: charged Pastrini to offer the two friends the key of his box at the Argentina
source_excerpt: The count had, moreover, charged him to offer the two friends the key of his box at the Argentina.

constraint_text: no tailor will consent to sew six buttons on a waistcoat for a crown per button for the next week
source_excerpt: for the next week you will not find a single tailor who would consent to sew six buttons on a waistcoat if you paid him a crown a piece for each button.

constraint_text: Glenarvan was familiar enough with the sea
source_excerpt: Glenarvan was familiar enough with the sea to understand the necessity of these arrangements.

constraint_text: Albert never forms an opinion except after long reflection
source_excerpt: Albert professed never to form an opinion except upon long reflection

constraint_text: The count believes Albert is a provincial because Albert has been absent from Paris for more than a year and his clothes are of an antiquated cut
source_excerpt: I have been more than a year absent from Paris, and my clothes are of a most antiquated cut; the count takes me for a provincial.

constraint_text: Danglars never gives more than four percent interest, generally only three and a half, but would give five percent to his son‑in‑law.
source_excerpt: I never give more than four per cent, and generally only three and half; but to my son‑in‑law I would give five, and we would share the profits.

constraint_text: Cavalcanti has a low‑born nature that sometimes escapes through his aristocratic gloss.
source_excerpt: yielding to his low‑born nature, which would escape sometimes through the aristocratic gloss with which he sought to conceal it.

constraint_text: Cavalcanti inherited at least two million from his mother, Leonora Corsinari.
source_excerpt: Truly, from my mother, Leonora Corsinari. I assure you I have never given the subject a thought, but I suppose it must have been at least two millions.

constraint_text: Caderousse has never seen the Tuileries.
source_excerpt: “Have you ever seen the Tuileries?” “No.”

constraint_text: The embarrassment completely escaped Albert, so he did not feel embarrassed.
source_excerpt: This embarrassment had completely escaped Albert

constraint_text: The embarrassment caused Lucien to shorten his visit.
source_excerpt: This embarrassment had completely escaped Albert, but it caused Lucien to shorten his visit

constraint_text: The baroness very rarely comes to the house.
source_excerpt: the baroness very rarely comes to the house

constraint_text: Morcerf's mother has visited Madame Danglars at most twice in her whole life.
source_excerpt: my mother, has not, I think, visited Madame Danglars twice in her whole life

constraint_text: Villefort's overwhelming politeness toward the speaker is in return for a service that the speaker rendered, which was enabled by a casual piece of good fortune.
source_excerpt: M. de Villefort has overwhelmed me with politeness in return for a service which a casual piece of good fortune enabled me to render him

constraint_text: Madame de Villefort had already met Maximilian Morrel at Auteuil, at the house of the Count of Monte Cristo, before the current encounter.
source_excerpt: "I have already had the pleasure of meeting this gentleman at Auteuil, at the house of the Count of Monte Cristo," replied Madame de Villefort

constraint_text: Morrel is described as one of the best and bravest officers.
source_excerpt: "M. Maximilian Morrel, captain of Spahis, one of our best, and, above all, of our bravest officers."

constraint_text: Faria has been regarded as a mad prisoner for many years, permitted to amuse visitors with his alleged insanity.
source_excerpt: I am the poor mad prisoner of the Château d’If, for many years permitted to amuse the different visitors with what is said to be my insanity

constraint_text: Faria believes attempting escape is impious because the Almighty does not approve of it.
source_excerpt: I perceive its utter impossibility; and I consider it impious to attempt that which the Almighty evidently does not approve.

constraint_text: The Count's judgment of another's bravery depends on how much he knows about that person
source_excerpt: “To tell the truth, count, if I knew less of you, I should think that you were less brave than you are.”

constraint_text: The Count has experienced a span of twenty years between life and death
source_excerpt: “What is it to me, who have passed twenty years between life and death?”

constraint_text: The Count believes that one must retire from the world politely and honestly, with a bow and debts of honor paid
source_excerpt: “I know the world is a drawing‑room, from which we must retire politely and honestly; that is, with a bow, and our debts of honor paid.”

constraint_text: The Count's weakness is disclosed only to Morrel
source_excerpt: “Moreover, do not alarm yourself, Morrel; this weakness, if it is such, is betrayed to you alone.”

constraint_text: Eugénie's pride is presented as the cause that may prevent her from ever returning to France.
source_excerpt: "The other night she left." "...I doubt whether her pride will ever allow her to return to France."

constraint_text: Danglars is characterized as the enduring "king of finance, the focus of immeasurable power".
source_excerpt: "you, the king of finance, the focus of immeasurable power."

constraint_text: must not exaggerate the evil
source_excerpt: "you must not exaggerate the evil," said Monte Cristo

constraint_text: must resolve upon one simple and single line of conduct
source_excerpt: "you must resolve upon one simple and single line of conduct,"

constraint_text: forming honorable friendships will counteract the prejudice attached to the obscurity of his former life
source_excerpt: "you must form honorable friendships, and by that means counteract the prejudice which may attach to the obscurity of your former life."

constraint_text: endeavoring to avoid one fault will cause him to fall into another fault
source_excerpt: "for by endeavoring to avoid one fault you will fall into another."

constraint_text: Maximilian states he will never be able to renounce the sentiment that has taken possession of his mind.
source_excerpt: I can never renounce the sentiment which has instinctively taken possession of my mind.

constraint_text: Maximilian believes it is ordained that the man should be associated with all the good which the future may have in store for him.
source_excerpt: I feel as if it were ordained that this man should be associated with all the good which the future may have in store for me

constraint_text: Maximilian believes the man's eye can see what is to come and his hand can direct events according to his own will.
source_excerpt: sometimes it really seems as if his eye was able to see what was to come, and his hand endowed with the power of directing events according to his own will

constraint_text: Maximilian has known the man for only eight to ten days.
source_excerpt: Scarcely longer than eight or ten days.

constraint_text: When he presented himself to the Count, Villefort was unaware that he would meet a person whose knowledge and understanding far surpass the usual knowledge and understanding of men.
source_excerpt: "when I presented myself to you, I was unaware that I should meet with a person whose knowledge and understanding so far surpass the usual knowledge and understanding of men"

constraint_text: It is not usual for corrupted wretches of civilization to find gentlemen of immense fortune.
source_excerpt: "It is not usual with us corrupted wretches of civilization to find gentlemen like yourself, possessors, as you are, of immense fortune—at least, so it is said"

constraint_text: It is not usual for privileged and wealthy beings to waste their time in speculations on the state of society.
source_excerpt: "it is not usual, I say, for such privileged and wealthy beings to waste their time in speculations on the state of society"

constraint_text: Madame Danglars will remain at home, read novels, and speculate at cards because she can no longer do so on the Bourse.
source_excerpt: “these are fine projects! She will remain at home, read novels, and speculate at cards, since she can no longer do so on the Bourse.”

constraint_text: M. Noirtier is a paralytic, a condition that persists over his lifespan.
source_excerpt: The paralytic closed his eyes in token of assent.

constraint_text: Her nickname 'La Carconte' was given because she was born in the village of La Carconte.
source_excerpt: The sobriquet of La Carconte had been bestowed on Madeleine Radelle from the fact that she had been born in a village, so called, situated between Salon and Lambesc;

constraint_text: She received the appellation La Carconte due to a local custom of styling people with distinctive names, which her husband applied to her.
source_excerpt: The custom existed among the inhabitants of that part of France where Caderousse lived of styling every person by some particular and distinctive appellation, her husband had bestowed on her the name of La Carconte in place of her sweet and euphonious name of Madeleine,

constraint_text: He continuously suffers the double misery of losing customers and profits and enduring his wife's constant murmurs and lamentations.
source_excerpt: let it not be supposed that amid this affected resignation to the will of Providence, the unfortunate innkeeper did not writhe under the double misery of seeing the hateful canal carry off his customers and his profits, and the daily infliction of his peevish partner’s murmurs and lamentations.

constraint_text: They remained constantly in a small waiting-room, ready to obey the summons of a small golden bell or the orders of the Romaic slave
source_excerpt: The first three remained constantly in a small waiting-room, ready to obey the summons of a small golden bell, or to receive the orders of the Romaic slave

constraint_text: They were instructed by Monte Cristo to treat Haydée with the deference due to a queen
source_excerpt: the latter had received most peremptory instructions from Monte Cristo to treat Haydée with all the deference they would observe to a queen

constraint_text: He was past fifty years old.
source_excerpt: a person, in a word, who, although evidently past fifty, desired to be taken for not more than forty

constraint_text: At that moment he wanted others to think he was no older than forty.
source_excerpt: a person, in a word, who, although evidently past fifty, desired to be taken for not more than forty

constraint_text: His cheek‑bones were broad and projecting, serving as a never‑failing proof of audacity and craftiness.
source_excerpt: his cheek-bones were broad and projecting, a never-failing proof of audacity and craftiness

constraint_text: He had twenty-one strawberries last year.
source_excerpt: "I had twenty-one, five more than last year."

constraint_text: He stole the missing strawberries.
source_excerpt: "It must be the son of Mère Simon who has stolen them; I saw him strolling about here this morning."

constraint_text: The maid remained downstairs after being told she was no longer needed.
source_excerpt: Since then the maid had been below, and like everyone else she thought the young ladies were in their own room

constraint_text: Mercédès feels she has aged more because of grief than because of years.
source_excerpt: Alas, I am grown old with grief more than with years

constraint_text: Mercédès has suffered much and has lived without any joy or hope.
source_excerpt: I too have suffered much; I repeat, it is melancholy to pass one’s life without having one joy to recall, without preserving a single hope; but that proves that all is not yet over.

constraint_text: Mercédès believes her situation is not yet finished because something still remains in her heart.
source_excerpt: No, it is not finished; I feel it by what remains in my heart.

constraint_text: He is very learned.
source_excerpt: That tall, harsh-looking man is very learned

constraint_text: His discovery of a lizard with an extra vertebra led to him being made an officer of the Legion of Honor.
source_excerpt: he discovered, in the neighborhood of Rome, a kind of lizard with a vertebra more than lizards usually have... and the gentleman, who was only a knight of the Legion of Honor, was made an officer

constraint_text: He was a knight of the Legion of Honor before being promoted.
source_excerpt: the gentleman, who was only a knight of the Legion of Honor

constraint_text: The speaker's life is dependent on cash
source_excerpt: My life belongs to my cash.

constraint_text: The speaker is brutal and boasts of it, which he claims is a reason for his commercial success
source_excerpt: I am brutal,—I not only allow it, but boast of it; it is one of the reasons of my success in commercial business.

constraint_text: Valentine habitually takes precautions (has usual precautions).
source_excerpt: who cast aside all her usual precautions and walked at once to the barrier

constraint_text: Maximilian had been awaiting Valentine's arrival for a long time.
source_excerpt: Maximilian had long awaited her coming

constraint_text: She had to use diplomacy to get rid of her watchful stepmother, too‑devoted maid, and troublesome brother in order to be able to meet the visitor.
source_excerpt: “And why do you come so late today? It is almost dinner-time, and I had to use no little diplomacy to get rid of my watchful stepmother, my too-devoted maid, and my troublesome brother, who is always teasing me about coming to work at my embroidery, which I am in a fair way never to get done.”

constraint_text: Andrea Cavalcanti must become a member of the family before he can be asked about the quarrel.
source_excerpt: When M. Andrea Cavalcanti has become one of the family, you can ask him that question.

constraint_text: His business makes him reflective
source_excerpt: M. de Morcerf is sometimes occupied, his business makes him reflective

constraint_text: It is necessary that we should be more than complaisant to the count
source_excerpt: It is necessary that we should be more than complaisant to the count.

constraint_text: He is twenty years old, an artist, has black hair and black eyes, and is traveling with his sister.
source_excerpt: “M. Léon d’Armilly, twenty years of age; profession, artist; hair black, eyes black; travelling with his sister.”

constraint_text: M. de Monte Cristo procured a man’s passport for Léon because he expressed his fears of travelling as a woman.
source_excerpt: “When I went to ask M. de Monte Cristo for letters to the directors of the theatres at Rome and Naples, I expressed my fears of travelling as a woman; he perfectly understood them, and undertook to procure for me a man’s passport, and two days after I received this, to which I have added with my own hand, ‘travelling with his sister.’”

constraint_text: The note that he is travelling with his sister was added to the passport two days after he received it.
source_excerpt: “...and two days after I received this, to which I have added with my own hand, ‘travelling with his sister.’”

constraint_text: Resolved not to send the money, but to take it to his brother himself
source_excerpt: "I loved my brother tenderly, as I told your excellency, and I resolved not to send the money, but to take it to him myself."

constraint_text: Possessed a thousand francs at the time of the narration
source_excerpt: "I possessed a thousand francs."

constraint_text: Publicly assassinated everybody they suspected of Bonapartism
source_excerpt: "Three brigands, called Trestaillon, Truphemy, and Graffan, publicly assassinated everybody whom they suspected of Bonapartism."

constraint_text: Franz had imagined the lady was still in Paris
source_excerpt: where indeed, he had imagined she still was

constraint_text: Maximilian fears offending Valentine because the difference between their respective stations causes that fear.
source_excerpt: "the difference between our respective stations makes me fear to offend you by speaking of my love"

constraint_text: Maximilian has chosen a trade.
source_excerpt: "I have chosen a trade."

constraint_text: He was freed from the hands of Signor Vampa.
source_excerpt: he merely came and freed me from the hands of Signor Vampa

constraint_text: He fears neither God nor Satan
source_excerpt: Ah, he is one who fears neither God nor Satan, they say, and would at any time run fifty leagues out of his course to do a poor devil a service.

constraint_text: He would at any time run fifty leagues out of his course to do a poor devil a service
source_excerpt: Ah, he is one who fears neither God nor Satan, they say, and would at any time run fifty leagues out of his course to do a poor devil a service.

constraint_text: Monte Cristo chose not to notice Albert because Albert looked angry and discomposed.
source_excerpt: He recognized Albert, but thought it better not to notice him, as he looked so angry and discomposed.

constraint_text: Luigi was not mistaken (he knew the correct road)
source_excerpt: Luigi was not mistaken.

constraint_text: The young woman is Greek.
source_excerpt: the young woman is a Greek.

constraint_text: The young woman is a musician.
source_excerpt: I do know one thing more, namely, that she is a musician, for one day when I chanced to be breakfasting with the count, I heard the sound of a guzla—it is impossible that it could have been touched by any other finger than her own.

constraint_text: M. de Villefort has secluded himself for the last week, making certain actions impossible.
source_excerpt: It was an impossibility; for the last week M. de Villefort has secluded himself.

constraint_text: If Debray spoke to the president, then Beauchamp must have been with the procureur.
source_excerpt: if I spoke to the president, _you_ must have been with the procureur.

constraint_text: Villefort claims he is not a man to bore his friends
source_excerpt: for I am not a man to bore my friends, as you will learn

constraint_text: Madame de Villefort is described as an eternal friend
source_excerpt: you have made an eternal friend of Madame de Villefort

constraint_text: Madame de Villefort killed the magistrate's father-in-law using poison
source_excerpt: where you conceal the poison by the aid of which you have killed my father-in-law, M.

constraint_text: The Count possesses marvellous sagacity (he understands the thoughts of others).
source_excerpt: the count’s marvellous sagacity understood all that was passing in the young girl’s mind.

constraint_text: Valentine is described as the tenderest father and the most respectful friend.
source_excerpt: the man standing before you, Valentine (for this time it is no ghost), is nothing more than the tenderest father and the most respectful friend you could dream of.

constraint_text: The narrator's father is dead while the narrator remains alive.
source_excerpt: My father died, but I did not die.

constraint_text: The narrator will die if the addressed person dies.
source_excerpt: If you were to die, I should die too.

constraint_text: The count habitually drives at a rapid pace.
source_excerpt: the count drove off at his usual rapid pace

constraint_text: Cocles has only one eye, and that eye has become dim over the course of nine years.
source_excerpt: as he had but one eye, and that eye had become somewhat dim in the course of nine years

constraint_text: He is accustomed to see his prisoners tremble before him.
source_excerpt: he was evidently accustomed to see his prisoners tremble before him

constraint_text: He acted like a gentleman throughout the whole affair.
source_excerpt: throughout this whole affair acted like a gentleman

constraint_text: Eugénie has experience dressing in the garb of the opposite sex
source_excerpt: with a promptitude which indicated that this was not the first time she had amused herself by adopting the garb of the opposite sex

constraint_text: Eugénie never feels cold
source_excerpt: “Oh, I am never cold, you know!”

constraint_text: Ayrton's cry is well known to his oxen, indicating the oxen recognize and respond to his call.
source_excerpt: He uttered a cry well known to his oxen, but there was no answer.

constraint_text: Ayrton is also known as Ben Joyce
source_excerpt: It is pronounced Ayrton, but it is written 'Ben Joyce'!

constraint_text: Danglars has seen his wife's actions continuously for the last sixteen years.
source_excerpt: I see, and always have seen, during the last sixteen years.

constraint_text: Danglars claims that no step, action, or fault of his wife has ever escaped his notice.
source_excerpt: not a step, not an action, not a fault, has escaped me

constraint_text: All of the woman's friends, from M. de Villefort to M. Debray, have trembled before Danglars.
source_excerpt: there is none of your friends, from M. de Villefort to M. Debray, who has not trembled before me.

constraint_text: His soul is no longer his own.
source_excerpt: I swear to you my soul is no longer my own.

constraint_text: He has no relation in the world.
source_excerpt: you know I have no relation in the world.

constraint_text: He regards Maximilian as his son.
source_excerpt: I have accustomed myself to regard you as my son

constraint_text: He is inflexible.
source_excerpt: you are inflexible

constraint_text: He is wretched.
source_excerpt: you are indeed wretched

constraint_text: Only a miracle can cure him.
source_excerpt: a miracle alone can cure you

constraint_text: Noirtier communicates by closing his eyes for 'yes' and winking for 'no' because he is deprived of voice and motion.
source_excerpt: M. Noirtier, being deprived of voice and motion, is accustomed to convey his meaning by closing his eyes when he wishes to signify ‘yes,’ and to wink when he means ‘no.’

constraint_text: Captain Mangles engaged to make Robert a sailor
source_excerpt: As Captain Mangles had engaged to make him a sailor, Glenarvan a man of honor, the major a boy of coolness, Lady Helena a noble and generous being, and Mary Grant a pupil grateful towards such patrons, Robert was evidently to become one day an accomplished gentleman.

constraint_text: Glenarvan engaged to make Robert a man of honor
source_excerpt: As Captain Mangles had engaged to make him a sailor, Glenarvan a man of honor, the major a boy of coolness, Lady Helena a noble and generous being, and Mary Grant a pupil grateful towards such patrons, Robert was evidently to become one day an accomplished gentleman.

constraint_text: The major engaged to make Robert a boy of coolness
source_excerpt: As Captain Mangles had engaged to make him a sailor, Glenarvan a man of honor, the major a boy of coolness, Lady Helena a noble and generous being, and Mary Grant a pupil grateful towards such patrons, Robert was evidently to become one day an accomplished gentleman.

source_excerpt: As Captain Mangles had engaged to make him a sailor, Glenarvan a man of honor, the major a boy of coolness, Lady Helena a noble and generous being, and Mary Grant a pupil grateful towards such patrons, Robert was evidently to become one day an accomplished gentleman.

constraint_text: Mary Grant engaged to make Robert a pupil grateful towards such patrons
source_excerpt: As Captain Mangles had engaged to make him a sailor, Glenarvan a man of honor, the major a boy of coolness, Lady Helena a noble and generous being, and Mary Grant a pupil grateful towards such patrons, Robert was evidently to become one day an accomplished gentleman.

constraint_text: Lady Helena's strong argument against the monkey theory is caused by the skill demonstrated in the construction and use of the boomerang.
source_excerpt: The skill manifested in the construction and use of this instrument served Lady Helena as a strong argument against the monkey theory

constraint_text: The Morcerfs depend on the union.
source_excerpt: "But you cannot break it off in this way; the Morcerfs are depending on this union."

constraint_text: Danglars is intimate with the Morcerf family.
source_excerpt: "you are so intimate with the family."

constraint_text: Danglars cannot break off the union in this way.
source_excerpt: "But you cannot break it off in this way; the Morcerfs are depending on this union."

constraint_text: He is a musician.
source_excerpt: "He is a musician."

constraint_text: He is well educated.
source_excerpt: "He is well educated."

constraint_text: He is very rich.
source_excerpt: "And he is very rich."

constraint_text: He loves to look at the sky even at night.
source_excerpt: That Count of Monte Cristo is an original, who loves to look at the sky even at night.

constraint_text: He has a secretary with a spring that catches a thief in a trap and plays a tune.
source_excerpt: Andrea, he has some secretaire with a spring.

constraint_text: When he goes to Auteuil and takes his servants, the house is left unprotected.
source_excerpt: You are imprudent, Monsieur Count; for when you go to Auteuil and take your servants the house is left unprotected.

constraint_text: He was poor in Dundalk
source_excerpt: He had left Dundalk, where he was poor, and, emigrating with his family to Australia, had landed at Adelaide.

constraint_text: He became a landed proprietor
source_excerpt: The Irish peasant had become a landed proprietor

constraint_text: He owned five hundred acres of well‑cultivated land and five hundred head of cattle
source_excerpt: he owned at that moment five hundred acres of well-cultivated land and five hundred head of cattle

constraint_text: His agricultural knowledge was a great aid to his success
source_excerpt: His agricultural knowledge was a great aid to him.

constraint_text: He was his own master and as independent as one can be
source_excerpt: was his own master, and as independent as one can be even in the freest country in the world.

constraint_text: The narrator asserts that God has not cursed them, implying they were never cursed.
source_excerpt: ‘God has not cursed me then,’ I cried, ‘since he permits me to save the life of a human creature, in exchange for the life I have taken away.’

constraint_text: The narrator knew that in Paris there was an asylum that received such creatures.
source_excerpt: I knew that at Paris there was an asylum where they receive such creatures.

constraint_text: The speaker once possessed a considerable portion of his fortune that was tolerable, but now he is ignorant of what has become of it.
source_excerpt: I am ignorant of what has become of a considerable portion of my fortune, once very tolerable

constraint_text: The wife is as conversant with the speaker's affairs as he is, and the speaker believes she understands them even better.
source_excerpt: you are as conversant with my affairs as I am; indeed, I think you understand them better

constraint_text: Noirtier's eye retained its inanimate expression
source_excerpt: Noirtier’s eye still retained its inanimate expression.

constraint_text: There was political hatred that had formerly existed between M. Noirtier and another party, which Villefort knew
source_excerpt: The procureur, who knew the political hatred which had formerly existed between M.

constraint_text: Madame Danglars is daring
source_excerpt: It is not he who plays! it is Madame Danglars; she is indeed daring.

constraint_text: M. Danglars is accustomed to play at gaining or losing 300,000 francs in a day
source_excerpt: I see that M. Danglars is accustomed to play at gaining or losing 300,000 francs in a day; he must be enormously rich.

constraint_text: Franz had never before experienced such a sudden transition from gayety to sadness in his whole life.
source_excerpt: In his whole life, perhaps, Franz had never before experienced so sudden an impression, so rapid a transition from gayety to sadness, as in this moment.

constraint_text: Noirtier has never been on strict terms of friendship with M. de Saint-Méran.
source_excerpt: M. de Saint-Méran and Noirtier had never been on strict terms of friendship;

constraint_text: Noirtier sent his old servant to inquire about the cause because he heard the noise in the house.
source_excerpt: who having heard the noise in the house, had, as we have said, sent his old servant to inquire the cause;

constraint_text: Luxuries in Albert's life have made his life easy and happy since his infancy.
source_excerpt: luxuries which had rendered life so easy and so happy since his infancy

constraint_text: Albert gave orders to his servant not to come to his room.
source_excerpt: notwithstanding orders to the contrary, came to his room

constraint_text: Villefort's ambition would cause him to sacrifice everything, even his father
source_excerpt: I told you Villefort was ambitious, and to attain this ambition Villefort would sacrifice everything, even his father.

constraint_text: M. de Villefort's father is Noirtier
source_excerpt: "His father?" "Yes, Noirtier."

constraint_text: Noirtier is identified as the Girondin and as a senator
source_excerpt: "Noirtier the Girondin?—Noirtier the senator?"

constraint_text: Paganel unhesitatingly sanctioned the search upon the American coast after the documents were submitted to him.
source_excerpt: when Paganel, in a moment of providential absent-mindedness, embarked on board our vessel, the documents were submitted to him, and he unhesitatingly sanctioned our search upon the American coast.

constraint_text: Cavalcanti's father promised him an annuity of 150,000 livres per year starting from the day Cavalcanti is married, if his father approves of his choice
source_excerpt: Thinking that I might wish to settle in France, he left me at his departure, together with the papers establishing my identity, a letter promising, if he approved of my choice, 150,000 livres per annum from the day I was married.

constraint_text: Danglars has always intended to give his daughter a dowry of 500,000 francs
source_excerpt: I,” said Danglars, “have always intended giving my daughter 500,000 francs as her dowry; she is, besides, my sole heiress.

constraint_text: Napoleon's desire changed after his son was born, contrary to the imperial police's wishes at that period.
source_excerpt: quite contrary to what Napoleon desired so soon as he had a son born to him, wished for a partition of provinces

constraint_text: The family no longer exists.
source_excerpt: No, no, be easy on that score; the family is extinct.

constraint_text: The narrator's hasty departure caused the imperial police to arrest him at the moment he was leaving Piombino.
source_excerpt: my hasty departure, the cause of which they were unable to guess, having aroused their suspicions, I was arrested at the very moment I was leaving Piombino

constraint_text: The vessel touched at Elba, where he quitted it, and he spent a whole day on the island.
source_excerpt: The vessel did touch at Elba, where he quitted it, and passed a whole day in the island.

constraint_text: Caderousse's caution supplanted his generosity after perceiving Danglars' reasoning.
source_excerpt: With the rapid instinct of selfishness, Caderousse readily perceived the solidity of this mode of reasoning; ... and then caution supplanted generosity.

constraint_text: Caderousse became determined to tell everyone about the deception.
source_excerpt: I am determined to tell them all about it.

constraint_text: Danglars promised to give his daughter only to a man who loves her, and not to one who does not.
source_excerpt: I have promised to give my daughter to a man who loves her, but not to one who does not.

constraint_text: Morcerf is cold as marble and proud like his father.
source_excerpt: See him there, cold as marble and proud like his father.

constraint_text: If Morcerf were rich or had Cavalcanti’s fortune, his shortcomings might be pardoned.
source_excerpt: If he were rich, if he had Cavalcanti’s fortune, that might be pardoned.

constraint_text: Paganel possessed a history and commentary for every sign‑board and announcement.
source_excerpt: Paganel had a history and commentary for every one.

constraint_text: He was loquacious and able to enlighten his guides.
source_excerpt: the services thus rendered charmed the Frenchman, who was none the less loquacious, and was in truth able even to enlighten his guides.

constraint_text: The narrator had been tracked by a customs-officer before being captured.
source_excerpt: I had been tracked by a customs-officer, who had lost sight of me near the tavern; feeling certain that I intended to pass the night there, he had returned to summon his comrades

constraint_text: Dantès' strength will be utterly exhausted in a few hours
source_excerpt: In a few hours my strength will be utterly exhausted;

constraint_text: The conviction that he is saved restored his strength
source_excerpt: And this conviction restored his strength.

constraint_text: His story will be accepted because there is no one left to contradict him
source_excerpt: My story will be accepted, for there is no one left to contradict me.

constraint_text: The Count of Monte Cristo despises all honors and is satisfied with only those written on his passport.
source_excerpt: “Ah, father,” said Albert with a smile, “it is evident you do not know the Count of Monte Cristo; he despises all honors, and contents himself with those written on his passport.”

constraint_text: The Count of Monte Cristo chose his career path, described as the path strewn with flowers.
source_excerpt: “You have been free to choose your career,” observed the Count of Morcerf, with a sigh; “and you have chosen the path strewed with flowers.”

constraint_text: Monte Cristo possesses a moral distrust of his best friends
source_excerpt: did I not possess a moral distrust of my best friends, and a sort of inclination to lead others to doubt them too;

constraint_text: Monte Cristo's moral distrust causes him to lead others to doubt his friends
source_excerpt: did I not possess a moral distrust of my best friends, and a sort of inclination to lead others to doubt them too;
